sentence: Shares of Microsoft (MSFT) might be trading at all-time highs, but that’s also because the software giant continues to exceed even the most-bullish Wall Street expectations, particular in its fast-growing cloud computing business.
The company its set to report fourth quarter and fiscal year 2017 earnings results after the closing bell Thursday.

For the quarter that ended June, the Redmond, Wash.-based tech giant is expected to deliver earnings per share of 71 cents on revenue of $24.27 billion, translating to year-over-year growth of 2.9% and 7%, respectively.
For the full year, earnings are projected to rise 8.6% year over year to $3.03 per share, while revenue of $96.24 billion would mark a year-over-year increase of $4.5%.
The blue-chip Dow component has seen its stock rise 19% year to date, while climbing some 40% over the past year, besting the S&P 500 in both spans.

Fresh of a 11% rise in its Intelligent Cloud business in the fiscal third quarter, during which products and cloud services revenue grew 15%, MSFT stock has been rewarded for CEO Satya Nadella’s cloud-first strategy, which has become a credible threat to Amazon’s (AMZN) dominant AWS cloud platform.
In the third quarter, revenue grew 7.5% year over year, driven by the company’s mobile first/cloud first strategy.
Notably, the 93% surge in Azure cloud revenue suggest that Microsoft is winning large enterprise deals versus the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM) and IBM (IBM).
On Thursday, however, analysts will want to see evidence that Microsoft’s cloud growth can continue to accelerate.
Likewise, the company earlier this month unveiled another business reorganization plan, aimed at strengthening cloud-related sales.
So, how Microsoft guides for fiscal 2018 will offer hints on the level of disruption analysts should expect.
In terms of hardware, Microsoft has also launched multiple devices, particularly in the Surface line, which the company expects will compete with high-end devices from Apple (AAPL).

Aside from competing with Apple, Microsoft’s new devices — some of which supports cross platform applications — are a crucial part of the company’s ecosystem build, helping to strengthen and boost adoption of cloud products such as Office365.
Because, thought the company is steering towards a cloud-first strategy, its core software suite — as part of its Office productivity segment — still generates tons of cash.
And we haven’t even mentioned the company’s position in gaming with the Xbox franchise and its social media prowess with LinkedIn.
In short, Microsoft is operating on all cylinders, especially when factoring its strengths in hardware, software and the cloud.
As such, investors who are looking for a potential breakout candidate, offering the combination of revenue growth and solid dividend can still do well here.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
